III. ABOUT THE POET
Wallace Stevens Bom 18T9
Died 1955
Wallace Stevens was an individualistic poet. Neither his personal
life nor his work seemed to fit into any established groove. Educated
at Harvard, he became a successful insurance lawyer. His poetic talent
developed late in his life - he was thirty-five when his poems were first
published - and his work was unique from the beginning. He was not influ¬
enced by other poets.
Most persistent in his poetry is the theme of the relationship between
stark reality and reality to which has been added one's imagination and
art. Stevens seemed to feel that emotion is vital to true rationality.
Stevendd elegant and ornamental language, used in ways that polish and
enrich his themes, is particularly noteworthy. His poetry demands careful
and attentive reading, and has therefore not been widely popular. Tat among
critics and discriminating readers alike, Stevens' work is admired for
its opulence of language, its subtleties of connotation, and its power.

and shingles (n. pi.)(thin pieces of material used to cover roofs and

disillusionment:
This word is central to the theme of the poem. It denotes "the process
of becoming free from illusion" and connotes depression and disappoint¬
ment aa well.
nightgowns;
This common noun is idiomatic in English. Notice the difference in these
similar forms: evening gowns (long dresses worn for formal social
events) and bedclothes (sheets, pillow cases and blankets).
